An old Mission with a great deal of history. The restoration of most of the buildings is well done and clearly shows the hardships of the original missionaries and in particular the Franciscan Friar Father Junipero Serra. The Serra Chapel has been restored and it has art works and a 17th Century Retablo or Golden Altar. Mass is still said here, daily. The stone church was built outside in 1806 but destroyed by an earthquake in 1812. The Serra Chapel was then reused until it became unsafe. The restoration in the 1920s added the Retablo. There is so much history from the Spanish to the Mexican and then the American times. At one point the Mission was a family home, during the Mexican period. So much more to see and do here. The Courtyard garden is beautiful. There are many volunteers tending to the gardens and working around the Mission.

I went to school at the Mission for 4th through 8th grade graduating in 1965. My fourth grade classroom was in one of the original adobe buildings. We spent a lot of time in the beautiful garden just outside our room. San Juan was much less crowded and a lot quieter back them. People came to visit the Mission, of course, but not in such numbers except maybe on Swallows' Day. All the kids dressed up in Spanish/Mexican clothing and danced to traditional music to entertain the tourists. The Mission is so very beautiful; you really should see it. It does seem to be a bit more commercialized these days. It is hard for me to pay for a ticket to visit my old school. Not so long ago, if I told someone I was an Old Mission student, they would let me in free of charge. Swallow's Day traditionally was on St. Joseph's Day, March 19. There is usually (always) a parade on or near that day. When you visit the Mission, be sure to cross the street to visit the Swallow's Inn for a bit to eat and a cold drink. If you are wondering why I only gave this wonderful place three bubbles, it is because of the crowds and commercialism. Maybe next time I'll go on a cold rainy winter day.

This mission has been extensively restored / reconstructed. Grounds are peaceful and pleasant, even on a hot summer day. There are numerous displays in the mission buildings tracing its history from the mission's heyday during the Spanish colonial period, through its decline under Mexican rule and later in the 19th century under American rule, to its resurgence as a historic site, tourist attraction, and place of pilgrimage during the early 20th century. The story of how the mission's promotion as a tourist destination during the early days of car touring helped spark its rebirth was very interesting. Definitely recommend taking some time to see this site while you are in Orange County.

The mission was founded November 1, 1776. The grounds are not very large; you can walk the grounds in about 2 hours. They give you the option for a free audio tour. The most prominent feature of this mission is the Ruins of the Old Stone Church, destroyed in an earthquake in 1812. Located next to the Stone church is a statue of Father Junipero Serra with a small Indian boy and just to the left of the statue is the bell wall. Within the buildings surrounding the central courtyard is Father Serra’s Chapel. This is the only known chapel, still standing, in which Father Serra is known to have preached. Located within the Serra Chapel is a prayer room dedicated to Saint Peregrine, patron saint of those who suffer from cancer.
There are also historical displays to be seen in the rooms surrounding the courtyard.
Admission is $9/adult with discounts for the aged, students and others. Well worth the price of admission and time to walk around this mission.

We went to see the Mission San Juan Capistrano, which is around 15 minutes by metro link from Irvine station.The ticket is only $ 6 per person , but getting to the station by Uber will cost you around $13, so it may save time by taking an Uber all the way (Around$30) and back.The historical district is just a row old houses from over the years, some pretty, and some old houses from the time of the early days of the town. The mission is just a few minutes walk from the picturesque railway station, and costs around $ 9 entry for an adult( Includes an audio guide). The volunteers at the reception are helpful and sweet.Lots of history here; within the mission is the oldest church in California which still conducts mass, the Serra chapel.Lovely flowers and cacti, amazingly cool corridors flanking the central courtyard with the garden.The exhibits from 1780s onwards, paintings( some lovingly restored), and the informative write ups gives one an appreciation of the life and times of the mission over more than two centuries.Some buildings and statues need more restorative work, some could be better maintained, and the toilets could be cleaner. The Mission industrial centre, with the vines and vegetable and fruit beds,the hide tanning area and the Tallow vats, the blacksmiths implements exhibit, all make for an interesting display.The Serra chapel is well restored, with its paintings and gold leaf covered wooden altar gleaming. Outside, flanking the chapel are more gardens , and a path leads to the bell wall with its 2 large and 2 small bells.This more or less completes the visit, and takes around 1 1/2 hours, perhaps more if you are very devout or very interested in history.The gift shop( strategically positioned as you leave), offers a lot of "swallow " ( The bird that epitomises the mission)motif gifts, a variety of crosses, jewellery, local mission produced jams, olive oil etc.Outside the mission there are similar souvenir shops, which are okay from some small gifts, but the silver and old' indian' jewellery is far too expensively priced.After exiting the mission don't forget to visit the grand, ornate and large Church, the Mission Basilica, located behind the mission, a few minutes walk away.Its time thereafter to get a refreshing drink and a bite to eat at one of the many eateries and wine tasting places, or you could try lunch at some of the historic and reputed restaurants around the area.We were home by 1 pm, having taken an Uber back.Great way to spend the morning.

Southern California is a wonderful place. I'm a native, and can't imagine living anywhere else. But if I've got one knock against the place (aside from the ridiculous traffic), it's that there's relatively little by way of history here. It's not to say we don't have it, there's just not a lot of it left to enjoy. The region loves to reinvent itself, usually at the cost of something that tells a story of how it used to be. Which is why Mission San Juan Capistrano is so important. This place is the real deal. A centuries old bit of living history, and an architectural treasure that offers sights and tells stories that you won't find anywhere else in the region. Spend as little or as much time as you wish here (although a few hours at least is my recommendation), it will do your heart good. They don't call it the Jewel of MIssions for nothing...it's as beautiful as anything you'll see in Southern California. And the (very) old Serra Chapel is not to be missed. Since traffic can be a problem in this stretch of the county, it's also worth noting that Metrolink deposits you quite literally steps away from the entrance. It's a rare attraction that's truly mass transit-friendly. In short, if you visit Southern California and miss this place, you've made a major mistake.

HISTORIC MISSION SAN JUAN -- A VISUAL SYMBOL OF CALIFORNIA HISTORY AND HERITAGE

Located on Camino Capistrano in the historic center of San Juan Capistrano, just west of the I-5 freeway interchange with Ortega Highway (CA-74), and within walking distance to Los Rios Historic District, El Adobe restaurant and the San Juan Capistrano train depot (Amtrak and MetroLink), the MISSION SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, founded in 1776 by Junipero Serra, is a national historic landmark and a visual symbol of the Spanish, Mexican, Indian and American heritage of California. The mission ruins are the home of world famous migrating swallows that return to the Mission every year on March 19. The Mission, with ruins of the former mission, well-manicured gardens, pleasant courtyard, fountains, flowers, archways audio tour, is an inspiring and stimulating experience. Parking is sometimes a problem; I recommend the parking structure at the train depot that is two blocks away.
